My favorite books of 2022 (in no particular order):

-The Transit of Venus, Shirley Hazzard
-Want, Lynn Steger Strong
-Species of Spaces and Other Pieces, Georges Perec
-A Tale of Two Cities, Charles Dickens
-Indelicacy, Amina Cain
-A Severed Head, Iris Murdoch
-Middlemarch, George Eliot (reread)

These books were some standouts in a not-so-stellar reading year. In 2023 I’m hoping for books that elicit stronger opinions and bigger emotions. The one thing I wouldn’t change are my interactions with this community. Thank you for all the conversation. Happy New Year!

.

#bestof2022 #endofyear #bookstagram #happynewyear #igreads #booksbooksbooks

If I had to sum up George Eliot’s Daniel Deronda in a single word, it would be “imperfect.” The word captures perfectly the noble striving of the book as well as its sometimes lack of imagination. The novel, Eliot’s last before she died, contains two plotlines that run parallel and at times intersect. There’s the story of beautiful Gwendolen Harleth who marries for money out of her own self interest and to provide for her mother, and then there’s Daniel Deronda, born into wealth but of unknown parentage, and whose journey to find himself leads to a deep affinity for Judaism.

Historically, readers and critics praised the Gwendolen story and dismissed the Jewish story, which was more likely than not motivated by Victorian prejudice. But many critiques of the book aren’t unfounded. The Daniel plotline suffers from too much mysticism and too often characters feel more identifiable by what they represent than their individual traits and values. I love Eliot’s books for their big ideas. I love the conversations that they spark between characters. But in Daniel Deronda, the ideas supersede the characters so that the sole purpose of one character is to be the “good” to another’s “bad.” Perhaps I’m being too harsh on my beloved George, but for someone who excels at making characters feel human, there is an essential humanness lacking here. And yet where Eliot lacks imagination in execution, she triumphs with empathic intent. Eliot sought to increase human understanding with her books (especially since she herself was an outsider—an unmarried woman in an illicit relationship, estranged from members of her family, and writing novels under a male pseudonym)—and the impact of a female Victorian novelist writing a book with positive Jewish representation cannot be understated. Eliot threw herself wholly into her writing, and in preparing for Daniel Deronda she attended synagogue, studied Jewish texts, and learned Hebrew. It paid off in capturing the authenticity of lived experience; Sigmund Freud said that George Eliot knew of things “we [Jews] speak of only among ourselves.” 

(Continued in comments below)

I’m giddy on crime. No, really! I can’t remember when I last had so much fun reading a book. The High Window by Raymond Chandler has all the makings for delicious hardboiled fiction: Pasadena heat, a mean asthmatic with a thirst for port, leggy blondes, hushed phone booth conversation, slick one-liners, and a chauffeur named Shifty. And high balls. So many high balls, often just a generous glug right from the bottle. Best read by imagining Humphrey Bogart narrating the whole thing. I loved this book!

“She had a lot of face and chin. She had pewter-colored hair set in a ruthless permanent, a hard beak and large moist eyes with the sympathetic expression of wet stones.”

“If you hire me, you’ll get all the delicacy I have. If I don’t have enough delicacy, maybe you’d better not hire me.”

“She started to get purple again.”

“He looked as if he had been sitting there since the Civil War and had come out of that badly.”

“No artery throbbed there, or even whispered.”

“Skip the agony, toots.”

.

#bookreview #raymondchandler #bookstagram #igreads #noir #mysteryfiction #crimefiction #bookish #alwaysreading #booksbooksbooks #bookaesthetic #bookdecor #momentsofmine #currentlyreading #bookclub

It’s strange to read a book when you know how it ends, especially a book whose tragic finish looms so large. I started Anna Karenina expecting to be surprised by nothing, but in a way I was surprised by everything. Good writing can do that—obliviate all expectations and render previous knowledge irrelevant. When you read Tolstoy, he forces all your focus on the present moment, so that picturing Anna’s fate at the end of the book is as unfathomable as picturing yourself as a person forty or fifty years from now; you know it will happen, but your brain can’t comprehend it.

So much of the beauty and achievement of Anna Karenina exists in its immediacy. I think of the ballroom scene where with a single look, Kitty is destroyed and Anna is reborn. I think of Levin, whose doubt plagues him with shame; who in his quiet intensity feels everything a little too deeply. I think of Stiva and his unflappable playfulness blinding him to responsibility; Vronsky’s disappointment with desire realized; and Anna’s tortured acceptance that a child born cannot replace a child left behind.

There is much to say about what this book achieves as a whole and the interplay between family and politics and class structure and gender, but others have said it better and I’ll leave it to them. For me, it was always going to be about the writing and the tension that Tolstoy creates in his characters—outwardly contained and inwardly flailing. And though I was invested in Anna’s story, it was Levin’s that moved me. The man who spends too much time thinking about what it is to live a good life and how to live a good life that he fumbles the actual living of a good life. “What did it mean? It meant that his life was good, but his thinking was bad.” Has anyone ever been more hopelessly human?

.

#bookreview #bookstagram #bookblogger #bookaesthetic #annakarenina #leotolstoy #translatedliterature #momentsofmine #thatsdarling #bookish #bookhub #bookworm #moka #booksandcoffee #igreads

Just realized that I’m unintentionally rereading the syllabus of my junior year American Modernism seminar. Eleven years later, these books are still favorites. Thanks, Professor Graham.

.

#americanmodernism #booksandcoffee #fscottfitzgerald #edithwharton #momentsofmine #thatsdarling #sundaymornings #currentlyreading #bookstagram #igreads #bookrecommendations

Where The Great Gatsby is a novel of economy (tight language; tighter plotting), Tender is the Night is a novel of excess. Everything is too much: the melodrama, the overtones of Freud, the language. The book is a tangled unspooling of sumptuous prose spilling in every direction, and while some parts feel carefully considered, others are spinning out like a car careening around a sharp bend. The novel opens on the shore of the French Riviera and immediately Fitzgerald drowns readers in lavish descriptions of scenery and characters. There is much to roll your eyes at in this book, starting with Rosemary, a Hollywood starlet fresh off the success of her picture Daddy’s Girl, without a father in real life, and helplessly in love with a married man some fifteen years her senior (ugh). And then there’s the object of her affection, Dick Diver, a psychoanalyst with a taste for alcohol and female patients (double ugh). But stay with me. This book is good, better than it has any right to be, mostly because of the writing. This book feels like a precursor to James Salter’s writing: languid and lush and just shy of being too enamored with itself. And though Fitzgerald’s psychoanalyzing all of his characters can be a bit much at times, he does produce some breathtaking nuggets of insight. 

“Nicole saw that one of his most characteristic moods was upon him, the excitement that swept everyone up into it and was inevitably followed by his own form of melancholy, which he never displayed but at which she guessed. This excitement about things reached an intensity out of proportion to their importance, generating a really extraordinary virtuosity with people. Save among a few of the tough-minded and perennially suspicious, he had the power of arousing a fascinated and uncritical love.”

I first read this book in college 11 years ago and fell in love with it. Upon rereading it for the first time, I was a little embarrassed by my deep love of it. Nonetheless, it remains a favorite.

#tenderisthenight #fscottfitzgerald #bookreview #igreads #bookstagram #americanmodernism #booksbooksbooks #alwaysreading #momentsofmine #thatsdarling #bookish #bookaesthetic

Rereading another book I first read in college. I don’t remember enjoying it at the time, but now I can’t put it down. 

“What we, or at any rate what I, refer to confidently as memory—meaning a moment, a scene, a fact that has been subjected to a fixative and thereby rescued from oblivion—is really a form of storytelling that goes on continually in the mind and often changes with the telling. Too many conflicting emotional interests are involved for life ever to be wholly acceptable, and possibly it is the work of the storyteller to rearrange things so that they conform to this end. In any case, in talking about the past we lie with every breath we draw.”

.

#bookstagram #igreads #litfic #currentlyreading #momentsofmine #thatsdarling #bookish #booksandcoffee #moka #pothos #bookaddict #bookaesthetic #booklover #bookdecor #alwaysreading

Starting my second to last George, Felix Holt: The Radical. This is often referred to as George Eliot’s political novel, though some argue it’s political only by being her “most insistently anti-political novel.” 

Felix Holt is her novel that I was least looking forward to, but a few pages in and Eliot has me alternating between swooning and guffawing. She is everything best.

.

#bookstagram #georgeeliot #felixholt #currentlyreading #momentsofmine #moka #mokapot #booksandcoffee #thatsdarling #igreads #bookish

Do people like museums?

The people like museums. And soup (but not getting souped). And parks. And books. And pickles. And whiskey. And sitting on steps. And Heartstopper. And patina (of cities and coffee pots). And the floor. And hot dogs. And moka. And phroth. And chocolate chips (but only two). And porches. And watercolors. And dumplings. And lucky cats. And ducks. And these people.

“I think it was Faulkner who once said that when you strike a match in a dark wilderness is it not in order to see anything better lighted, but just in order to see how much more darkness there is around. I think that literature does mainly that. It is not really supposed to ‘answer’ things, not even to make them clearer, but rather to explore—often blindly—the huge areas of darkness, and show them better.”—Javier Marías

I couldn’t explain this book if I tried. To try to explain would be to attempt to distill meaning, and per Marías—books are for exploring huge areas of darkness. There is nothing clean or conclusive about literature. A Heart So White exemplifies this beautifully. 

On Marías’ Wikipedia page, it says that all of the protagonists from his novels are interpreters or translators. Marías himself worked as a translator, and of these characters he said, “They are people who are renouncing their own voices.” Yes, and with this comes so much attention to language and the said and not said. The back cover summary reveals that the novel is about a family secret, and sure, but the secret is just a prop. It’s a juicy prop, but the meat of the book is language and listening and talking and silences and doing and not doing. “The day we didn’t spend together we will never have spent together, what someone was going to say to us over the phone when they called and we didn’t answer will never be said, at least not exactly the same thing said in exactly the same spirit; and everything will be slightly different or even completely different because of that lack of courage which dissuades us from talking to you.” There are a hundred other lines like this in the book that say the same thing and also negate it, and I underlined every single one of them. This is the book that reawakened my brain during and after the horrors of moving. Marías’ sentences are full of shadows and sophistication in a not too showy way that my brain found deeply satisfying.

.

#bookstagram #bookreview #translatedfiction #igreads #bookish #momentsofmine #booksandcoffee #javiermarias #spanishliterature #bookaesthetic #bookdecor #thatsdarling #booksbooksbooks #bookobsessed

When it comes to discussing qualities I admire in books, humor has somehow become the overlooked middle child. That’s on me. But in general I feel like we don’t talk about humor in books enough—how curative it is and how it pops up in such unsuspecting places! Of course I knew what I was getting into when I picked up the Wodehouse. His name has become synonymous with delicious uppercrust hijinks. But who knew that Melville was so funny—not me! And humor is so difficult. It’s so hard to be funny, whether subtly or unabashedly. There is so much effort in pulling off something that has to appear effortless at all costs (or else it simply won’t work)—something which both of these books do with aplomb. 

.

#bookstagram #bookrecommendations #bookreview #pgwodehouse #melville #bartleby #literaryfiction #alwaysreading #momentsofmine #booksbooksbooks #bookworm #bookish #bookaesthetic #bookdecor #readmorebooks

Virginia Woolf famously called Middlemarch "one of the few English novels written for grownup people." “Novels for grownup people” can be interpreted in many different ways, but I take it to mean that they’re novels about the inherent messiness of life. If Woolf were alive today, I’d like to think that she’d welcome Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan quartet as the Italian counterparts to Middlemarch, as far as novels for “grownup people” go. Ferrante’s Nino is no Casaubon (he is worse, much worse), but Middlemarch and Ferrante’s books focus on human nature and how we misjudge it and how we fight it and give into it and its streak of unpredictability, and when presented with this, our emotional tolerance, whether for human folly or cruelty, is tested and forced to expand. 

Each book in Ferrante’s quartet pushes the boundaries of betrayal and motivation so that my own understanding of friendships and relationships and human behavior grew more and more amorphous while reading them. Everything that I thought I knew struggled to find relevance in the Naples of Lila and Lenù and their 6-decades-long friendship. It’s not that anything that happens within this world is so fantastic that it borders on the impossible to believe (although the drama abounds); but through her writing, Ferrante makes it clear that her knowledge of the human psyche and our ability to hurt and endure is so intimate and expansive that my own understanding in this area became a mere speck of dust next to her heaping tower. 

Going back to Woolf’s quote, I love it because to declare that a book about the quiet lives of people in a small English town is “one of the few written for grownup people” feels subversive. There is nothing worldly or sophisticated about Middlemarch, and Ferrante’s Neapolitan quartet feels similarly radical. A story about life in a neighborhood in Naples—the poverty, the violence, the insularity—and at its center a friendship between two women.

(Continued in comments)

Revenge is a dish best dressed in wool. What at first seems like savage precociousness is in fact savage retribution. No one could pull off this feat quite like Helen DeWitt and no one has earned the right more than her to raise a resplendent middle finger to the publishing industry. 

“The French understand wine, cheese, and bread.

The Belgians understand chocolate.

The Italians understand coffee and ice cream.” 

DeWitt understands vengeance in all its pent up and deliciously executed release.

Brava!

.

Quotes from Laurie Colwin, patron saint of the biscuit cutter, self-proclaimed cook of the refined slob variety:

“I have kind of a crush on biscuit cutters, and when I see them at flea markets I always buy them.”

“It is not hard to dote on black beans.”

“Black beans are the frazzled person’s friend.”

“I am a great fan of things that cook while you dream or work.”

“Cookbooks hit you where you live. You want comfort; you want security; you want food; you want to not be hungry; and not only do you want those basic things fixed, you want it done in a really nice, gentle way that makes you feel loved.”

“I am a fool for a biscuit cutter.”

“I am addicted to lima beans, which I feel have an undeservedly bad reputation. They are pillowy, velvety, and delicious, and people should stop saying mean things about them.”

“Whatever it was, I tried not to disgrace myself by eating enormous quantities of it, but I was not successful.”

“I was at a cocktail party not too long ago, and someone started talking about Anna Karenina, and whoever this person was filled me with such a blinding desire to read this book that I felt that I had to get out of there at once and find a copy and read it. Well, fortunately, they had one on the shelf. So I said, ‘Excuse me, could I borrow this book?’ They said, ‘Sure.’ I said, ‘Bye!’ and I left.”

.
